resource.title: Imaging Recommendations and Rationale
resource.description: Comprehensive recommendations and their underlying rationale for diagnostic imaging in a critically ill patient.

detail.description: Perform a focused, contrast-enhanced CT angiography of the chest (arterial phase) to specifically assess the thoracic aorta. Omit abdominal and pelvic imaging unless clinically indicated.
Utilize a low-volume, weight-based contrast dose (approximately 80-100 mL of high-iodine-concentration agent) with a split-bolus or single-phase arterial protocol to minimize iodine load.
If hemodynamic instability precludes safe transport, consider bedside transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) or focused cardiac ultrasound as an alternative imaging modality.
Schedule follow-up renal labs (creatinine, eGFR) at 24 and 48 hours post-contrast to monitor for acute kidney injury.

note.text: Tailors imaging to the primary diagnosis of thoracic aorta injury, reducing unnecessary contrast exposure and scan time.
Minimizes nephrotoxic load in a hypotensive patient, aligning with ACR guidelines for contrast media.
Addresses the risk of transport in a critically ill, hypotensive patient by suggesting alternatives.
Essential for early detection of contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) in a patient with hemodynamic instability.

action.description: Details for performing Contrast-enhanced CT of the chest optimized for evaluation of the thoracic aorta.

action.title: Indications
action.description: Traumatic aortic injury, Suspected aortic dissection, Aortic aneurysm evaluation

action.title: Contrast Dose
action.description: Weight-based, ~80-100 mL of high-iodine-concentration (e.g., 370 mg I/mL) iodinated contrast. Consider split-bolus technique for optimal aortic opacification.

action.title: Renal Safety Notes
action.description: Use lowest effective volume and concentration. Confirm contrast-to-eGFR ratio. Monitor for signs of CIN. Consider iso-osmolar contrast if patient is volume depleted and fluid overload is a concern.
